Expectation1: Ensure client satisfaction and address any concerns or complaints professionally
Situation1: A first-time visitor looks disappointed with the colour tone in the mirror.
Expectation2: Recite and reflect on the Quran
Situation2: A relaxed evening lies ahead with no other commitments.
Story: I stood behind my client, watching her eyes flicker with uncertainty as she examined her new hair color in the mirror. She hesitated, then quietly said, “It’s a bit brighter than I expected.” My heart sank. As a hairdresser, I knew I had to address her concern, reassure her, maybe even redo the color if she asked. I glanced at the clock—my last appointment of the day. I had been looking forward to this evening, planning to recite and reflect on the Quran in peace, something I hadn’t done in days. The salon was finally quiet, and I could almost feel the tranquility waiting for me at home. But now, I could sense the tension rising inside me, torn between my duty to my client and my longing for spiritual fulfillment. I tried to steady my voice, offering her a seat and a cup of tea, but inside, I was wrestling with the weight of both roles, unsure which expectation I would have to set aside tonight.
